message.content:
cs.CV, cs.LG, cs.MM, cs.AI, cs.NE 

The paper deals with human action recognition in videos using deep learning techniques, specifically convolutional neural networks. This falls under the computer vision (cs.CV) sub-category. The paper also proposes a new architecture for handling 3D signals more effectively, which involves factorizing the convolution kernel learning process. This is a novel approach to deep learning and could potentially fall under the machine learning (cs.LG) sub-category. Additionally, the paper involves the use of sampling multiple video clips from a given action video sequence to address the issue of sequence alignment, which could fall under the multimedia (cs.MM) sub-category. The paper also involves the use of auxiliary training videos to boost performance, which could fall under the artificial intelligence (cs.AI) sub-category. Finally, the paper involves the use of a novel transformation and permutation operator, which could fall under the neural and evolutionary computing (cs.NE) sub-category.
